awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Real-Time Allergen Detection Technology for Dietary Proteins Transferred to Human Milk
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide the first test to determine the allergen content of human milk accurately, quickly, and cost-effectively. As much as 25% of infants have reported allergic responses to dietary proteins found in human milk which often results in breast/body feeding termination. Breast/body feeding is incredibly beneficial to health and continuation of nursing is a human health issue. Studies indicate that human milk is superior to hypoallergenic formula, providing natural antibodies to fight illness, lowering the risk of sudden infant death syndrome, and reducing the probability of developing disorders such as diabetes and leukemia. There is currently no at-home, real-time test for milk allergens on the market.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to develop a real-time at-home allergen detection test. This project lays the groundwork for providing the first mechanism to research early and often allergen introduction through human milk when the immune system has been shown to be susceptible to allergy reduction strategies. The company’s patent-pending technology has the potential to provide a tool to identify allergens quickly and cost-effectively, allowing parents to monitor the presence of likely allergen triggers. The test is performed by the user in a real-time, in an at-home setting, which is a significant advantage over existing tests that require samples to be sent to a laboratory for labor and resource-intensive assays. The lateral flow technology provides a rapid and easy-to-read result, allowing the user to quickly determine whether the milk contains specific non-human protein fragments which are also known to elicit allergic responses in some patients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report:

This NSF-funded project focused on developing a user-friendly, at-home test kit to detect dietary proteins in human breastmilk. Specifically, the lateral flow device (LFD) we developed helps parents identify cow’s milk proteins in their breastmilk, providing crucial insights for managing food allergies in infants, such as Food Protein-Induced Enterocolitis Syndrome (FPIES) and Food Protein-Induced Allergic Proctocolitis (FPIAP).

Intellectual Merit:

The project achieved significant scientific advancements, particularly in the fields of human milk proteomics and at-home diagnostic technologies. The LFD was developed using advanced monoclonal antibodies targeting key cow’s milk proteins, such as beta-lactoglobulin and alpha-s1-casein. Proteomic analysis played a key role in optimizing the sensitivity and specificity of the test, ensuring it could detect even low concentrations of these proteins in human breastmilk (down to 0.1 µg/mL). The successful validation of the LFD marks an important step forward in creating accessible, affordable diagnostic tools for food allergy management.

Additionally, human factors testing across five cohorts enabled us to refine the test kit to ensure it is simple and intuitive to use at home. Feedback from real users led to the addition of video tutorials and step-by-step instructions, improving both the usability and accuracy of the test. The iterative design process combined scientific rigor with user-centered design to produce a reliable and accessible diagnostic tool.

Broader Impacts:

The development of this LFD addresses a critical gap in early allergy detection and dietary management, especially for infants who may be sensitive to proteins in their mother’s breastmilk. The test empowers parents to take a proactive role in managing their child’s food sensitivities, potentially reducing the risk of severe allergic reactions and improving quality of life for families dealing with food allergies.

In addition to its immediate health benefits, this project has broader societal impacts. By providing an affordable and easily accessible tool for at-home use, the LFD lowers barriers to early diagnosis, especially in communities with limited access to pediatric healthcare. This aligns with broader public health goals of promoting preventative care and reducing healthcare disparities.

The project also contributed to the development of human resources in science and technology. Team members received specialized training in human milk proteomics, diagnostic device development, and human factors testing, gaining valuable skills that will advance their careers in biotechnology and healthcare innovation.

Key Outcomes:

  • Developed a lateral flow device (LFD) capable of detecting cow’s milk proteins in breastmilk, validated for sensitivity and specificity across a range of concentrations.
  • Incorporated proteomic analysis to improve the design and accuracy of the test, resulting in a product that can detect proteins at levels as low as 0.1 µg/mL.
  • Conducted human factors testing to ensure the test is intuitive and easy for parents to use at home, leading to improved usability scores and user satisfaction.
  • Made meaningful contributions to public health by addressing the unmet need for early detection of food allergies in infants.
  • Trained scientists and researchers in advanced diagnostics and human milk proteomics, contributing to the development of the next generation of experts in the field.

This project has not only advanced scientific understanding but has also created a tool with the potential to improve the lives of countless families.

 


Last Modified: 10/05/2024
Modified by: Trillitye R Paullin

Project Outcomes Report:


This NSF-funded project focused on developing a user-friendly, at-home test kit to detect dietary proteins in human breastmilk. Specifically, the lateral flow device (LFD) we developed helps parents identify cows milk proteins in their breastmilk, providing crucial insights for managing food allergies in infants, such as Food Protein-Induced Enterocolitis Syndrome (FPIES) and Food Protein-Induced Allergic Proctocolitis (FPIAP).

The project achieved significant scientific advancements, particularly in the fields of human milk proteomics and at-home diagnostic technologies. Proteomic analysis played a key role in optimizing the sensitivity and specificity of the test, ensuring it could detect even low concentrations of these proteins in human breastmilk (down to 0.1 g/mL). Additionally, human factors testing across five cohorts enabled us to refine the test kit to ensure it is simple and intuitive to use at home. Feedback from real users led to the addition of video tutorials and step-by-step instructions, improving both the usability and accuracy of the test. The iterative design process combined scientific rigor with user-centered design to produce a reliable and accessible diagnostic tool.
